;专家们在 2018 年对自周日以来失踪的潜水船提出了安全担忧，

;

;飞行员和四名乘客在船上，船上的可用氧气预计将在美国东部时间星期四早上耗尽（香港时间星期四晚上）。

;

;Titan 潜水器是一艘 6.7 米长的船只，由总部位于华盛顿埃弗里特的 OceanGate Expeditions 运营。

;

;它首先下潜到 4,000 米据该公司网站称，该公司于 2018 年 12 月下潜至 13,100 米（13,100 英尺），并于 2021 年首次潜入泰坦尼克号遗址——大西洋下方约 3,800 米处。该公司计划今年进行 18 次此类潜水。

;

;但一些行业专家和一名举报员工担心它的安全性，并表示担心 OceanGate 选择不通过美国航运局（领先的潜水器分级机构）或欧洲集团 DNV 等第三方对泰坦进行认证，一家独立的质量保证和风险管理公司，为水下航行器的设计安全制定标准。

;

;同行评审小组海洋技术协会 (MTS) 载人潜水器委员会主席 Will Kohnen 在一封信中致辞日期为 2018 年 3 月 27 日，致 OceanGate 创始人兼首席执行官 Stockton Rush，他正在驾驶失踪的车辆。

;

;随着时间和空气的短缺，丢失的泰坦尼克号潜艇的可能结果

;

;在在信中，Kohnen 表达了他所说的对 Titan 的普遍担忧，Kohnen 说他后来与 Rush 讨论了这封信。

;

;“我们进行了坦率的谈话。这是一次成人谈话。我们同意不同意，”Kohnen 周三在谈及他与 Rush 的电话时告诉路透社。

;

;问题不是任何单一的设计缺陷，而是 OceanGate 选择不追求潜水器的行业公认认证程序设计、制造和测试。

;

;“我们担心 OceanGate 目前采用的实验方法可能会导致负面结果（从轻微到灾难性的），这将对行业中的每个人造成严重后果，”阅读

;

;Kohnen 说，这封信是在许多潜水专家在为期三天的年度研讨会上表达了对 Titan 的担忧之后发出的。他说他要求 MTS 董事会代表整个社会发送这封信，但董事会拒绝了。

;

;“我支持这封信以及我们成员的所有担忧情绪，”Kohnen 说. “说‘天啊，我们希望这不会发生’是没有意思的。”

;

;OceanGate、ABS 和 DNV 没有立即回应置评请求。

;

;Kohnen 将 Titan 的实验性质通知乘客归功于 OceanGate。 11 月，CBS 新闻播出了一名记者的报道，该记者阅读了他在登上 Titan 之前必须签署的弃权书，该弃权书将其确定为“未经任何监管机构批准或认证的实验性潜水船，可能会导致人身伤害，情感创伤或死亡”。

;

;据《纽约时报》报道，与船只和其他船只不同，潜水器在很大程度上不受监管，尤其是在国际水域作业时。

;

;1 月 18 日, 2018 年，根据 Lochridge 和 OceanGate 当年相互提起的诉讼，OceanGate 员工 David Lochridge 向公司领导转发了一份他撰写的工程报告，该报告对 OceanGate 的 Titan 研发过程提出了批评。

;

;Lochridge 尤其担心船体使用的材料，以及缺乏对船体进行的测试以衡量其承受深水巨大压力的能力。

;

;失踪的泰坦尼克号潜艇的老板曾被召唤根据诉讼，他的行业“非常安全”

;

;公司第二天召开会议讨论 Lochridge 的担忧。在会议结束时，Lochridge 表示他不能接受 OceanGate 的设计决定，并且不会在没有进一步测试的情况下授权任何载人航行。然后他被解雇了。

;

;OceanGate 于 2018 年 6 月和 7 月对 Lochridge 提起诉讼，指控他与至少另外两人讨论过机密信息。 Lochridge 于 2018 年 8 月提出反诉，否认并声称 OceanGate 的诉讼是为了阻止“举报者提出威胁无辜乘客安全的质量控制问题和安全问题”。

;

;OceanGate 做到了不回应置评请求。洛克里奇通过他的律师表示，他不予置评。 Kohnen 说他的信不是基于 Lochridge 的抱怨。

;

;OceanGate 的创始人 Rush 说安全是“纯粹的浪费”。

;

;“我的意思是如果你只是想成为安全，不要起床，不要上车，什么都不要做，”拉什在 2022 年与 CBS 记者大卫·波格 (David Pogue) 的播客中说。 “在某些时候，你会冒一些风险，这确实是一个风险回报问题。”

;

;由于柬埔寨犹豫不决是否参加有史以来第一次威胁东南亚统一区域范围内的联合海军演习，分析人士表示，即使没有一个或多个国家的参与，演习仍应继续进行。

;

;印度尼西亚军事总司令尤多·马戈诺最近在巴厘岛举行的东盟国防部长会议后表示，10 -成员地区机构将在南海举行首次联合军事演习。

;

;演习将以海上安全和救援行动为重点，不涉及作战行动。

;

;关于周二，印度尼西亚军方表示，东南亚国家联盟（东盟）成员已就将于 9 月 18 日至 25 日举行的联合演习举行初步规划会议。

;

;然而，此后不久最初宣布后，柬埔寨皇家武装部队总司令 Vong Pisen 将军发布了一份声明，称柬埔寨尚未同意演习。

;

;他说，虽然印度尼西亚提出了这个想法，但欧盟轮值主席国柬埔寨和“其他几个国家”（未具名）均未作出回应。

;

;马尼拉国际发展与安全合作智囊团常驻研究员约书亚·伯纳德·埃斯佩尼亚 (Joshua Bernard Espeña)，他说，柬埔寨对演习犹豫不决，因为它在地缘政治和经济上依赖中国。

;

;他说，如果东盟成员国的目标是定期举行海军演习，可以邀请非参与国家的军事代表，因为

;

;“[这是]保持东盟团结一致的信息，”Espeña 说，并指出虽然缅甸同样依赖中国，但由于内部冲突，它不会参加 9 月的会议。

;

;印尼军方已证实内比都拒绝参加。

;

;自 2021 年 2 月政变夺权以来，缅甸军政府一直卷入抵抗武装战争

;

;柬埔寨在援助、贸易和投资方面严重依赖中国，在 1994 年至 2021 年期间，北京占这个东南亚小国外国直接投资总额的 44%。

;

;新加坡 ISEAS-Yusof Ishak 研究所东盟研究中心协调员 Joanne Lin Weiling 表示，柬埔寨对将在南中国海举行的海军演习地点持谨慎态度。

;

;如果林说，他们没有在那里进行“这对柬埔寨来说可能更容易接受”，并指出金边参加了其他东盟演习，例如上个月在菲律宾苏比克湾水域举行的 2023 年东盟多边海军演习。< /p>;

;雅加达最初表示，9 月份的联合演习将在印度尼西亚纳土纳群岛东北部海域（即北纳土纳海）进行。

;

;纳土纳群岛位于印度尼西亚的专属经济区内，但也属于北京宣称拥有主权的南中国海海域。

;

;然而，雅加达周二表示，目前正计划在南纳土纳海域进行演习，该海域就在北京宣布的九段线之外

;

;林表示，柬埔寨支持东盟合作，加强东南亚的海上安全，应对共同挑战。林补充说：“只要不激怒其他各方或加剧区域水域的紧张局势，”他指出，对于那些对印度尼西亚的倡议“感到满意”的国家，联合演习应该继续进行。

;

;提到东盟海岸警卫队论坛由印度尼西亚于 11 月发起，旨在加强海上安全，林说只有八个东盟国家参加，柬埔寨和缅甸没有参与。

;

;其成员国，务实很重要，”林说，并补充说，无法获得所有 10 个东盟成员国支持的倡议可能仍会与最直接参与的成员国一起推进。

;

;“其他成员国可能”她说。

;

;虽然东盟的中心地位和团结对于该组织的有效性很重要，但该区域集团只是一个促进合作的政府间组织，Lin 补充道。< /p>;

;“东盟成员国当然不需要与外交或安全政策保持一致，也不需要在涉及该地区大国竞争的其他问题上保持一致，”她说。

;

;亚利桑那州立大学雷鸟全球管理学院副教授 Sophal Ear 表示，柬埔寨的不确定性反映出它不想“与铁定的朋友中国搅局”。

;

;“任何参与的人都是冒犯中国。任何不参与的人都与中国站在一起，”厄尔说，并补充说，如果柬埔寨不参与，东盟的团结和中心地位——“显然不是那么坚如磐石”——将受到破坏。

;

;但是Ear 指出，演习应该继续进行，因为参加的国家将改善其海军行动和联合能力。

;

;

;

;9 月的演习将是自该机构成立以来的首次东盟联合演习成立于 1967 年。

;

;西苏门答腊安达拉斯大学国际关系讲师 Rifki Dermawan 表示，虽然其他国家也可能出于担心惹恼中国而决定不参加演习，但与他们一起前进将发出一个强烈的信号，表明东盟正在集体保护该地区。

;

;“中国不是该地区的唯一威胁，”Rifki 说，并指出像 Aukus（澳大利亚、英国和美国）和四方（澳大利亚、美国、日本和印度）已经加剧了紧张局势。

;

;这迫使东盟计划演习以确保其在该地区的中心地位和相关性Rifki 补充说，这是大国竞争的结果。

;

;Espeña 表示，演习向美国和中国发出了信息，即华盛顿“不能指望东盟联合起来对抗中国”，北京也无法劝阻地区国家放弃

;

;Iseas 的 Lin 指出，大国争端正在加剧，美国和中国都在该地区进行了更多的军事演习。

;

;其中包括美国与多个东盟国家的“超级鹰之盾”和“金色眼镜蛇”演习、中国与泰国的“猎鹰打击”空军联合训练以及中国与老挝的“友谊之盾”演习。

;

;安缦友谊-2023（中国、柬埔寨、老挝、马来西亚、泰国和越南之间的和平与友谊 (Peace and Friendship-2023) 演习也计划在今年晚些时候举行。

;

;自己的平台来促进区域合作，”Lin 说。

;中国太平间兼作灵堂的邻居说他们是被迫的忍受不断的哭泣和哭泣的他们制作了一段他们的困境的视频，以在大陆社交媒体上获得支持。

;

;在热门视频中，一位来自中国北部河北省石家庄市的焦姓居民为她发声太平间距离她的公寓只有 50 米，这让她感到沮丧。

;

;据焦女士说，持续不断的哀号声和哭声使邻居无法打开窗户或无法入睡，造成严重的心理困扰。

;

;“凌晨 4 点，我们被哭声吵醒。然后他们从早上 5 点到上午 11 点播放悲伤的音乐。中午有短暂的停顿，但随后又恢复到下午 5 点，”她告诉《海峡都市邮报》。

;

;“当前的周期已经连续三天进行。但是，一个家庭的葬礼一结束，几天后另一个家庭的葬礼就开始了。”

;

;争议延伸到太平间的建设和其他邻居（包括焦）居住的住宅楼。

;

;焦说她是2008年买的，2019年太平间还没建。不过，太平间发言人称住宅楼是太平间后建的。

;

;“我们已经通知住户了关于太平间的位置。发言人说，当时应该有购买公寓的补贴。

;

;噪音已经迫使一些居民搬迁。

;

;工作人员表示他们会降低噪音水平

;

;该视频在大陆社交媒体上引起强烈反响和讨论。

;

;一位网友评论说：“不应该太平间建在火葬场还是医院？为什么要建在路边？抛开迷信不谈，持续不断的噪音非常令人不安！”

;

;另一人补充说：“如果只是暂时的，也许我能理解。但如果他们建立一个永久性太平间，那必须拆除。”

;

;第三个人说：“如果一个人在家，他们会被吓死！”

;

;据根据中国生态环境部发布的年度报告，在 2021 年收到的 45 万起环境投诉中，噪音干扰占 45%，仅次于空气污染投诉。

;

;为解决这一问题，中国修订了2022 年 6 月颁布的《噪声污染防治法》对居民区附近的噪音扰民处以最高 20 万元人民币（2.8 万美元）的罚款。

;

;今年早些时候，中国中部的一家医院被罚款 5.6 万元人民币屋顶空调噪音过大。

Recent incidents raise concerns over quality of drivers, but industry leaders say new measures needed to lure younger workershttps://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/law-and-crime/article/3224938/how-safe-are-hong-kong-taxis-recent-incidents-raise-concerns-over-quality-drivers-industry-leaders?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.22 09:00;
;;

;Alex Li can still vividly recall the moment his taxi driver fell asleep and the vehicle almost crashed into a barrier on a Hong Kong road.

;

;“We were on a highway, but the cabby fell asleep and lost control of the vehicle, which cut across two lanes on its own,” the 36-year-old technician said. “It was really risky.”

;

;When they arrived at the destination, luckily unharmed, Lee tipped the driver HK$500 (US$63) and urged him to end his shift immediately and get some rest.

;

;For a young business executive, who did not want to be identified, the cab dashboards lined with mobile phones providing constant updates on pickup requests is worrying.

;

;“Sometimes the cabbies start to drive off when the passengers are still getting out of the vehicles, and many drivers have a number of devices on their dashboards,” the 30-year-old woman said. “It looks really dangerous.”

;

;Concerns over the safety of taxi passengers have increased after two cabbies lost control of their vehicles and drove off the side of the road down a slope last week. The two unrelated incidents occurred on Magazine Gap Road on Tuesday and on Shing Mun Lane on June 14

;

;Earlier this week, a 55-year-old cabby was charged with false imprisonment after he allegedly dropped off a tourist at a Tsim Sha Tsui hotel and drove off with the man's wife. He allegedly took her to a construction site in Kwun Tong and kept her there for about 30 minutes.

;

;In March, at least three people were injured after a taxi was suspected to have lost control and ploughed into pedestrians at a crossing while driving downhill in Fortress Hill. The 84-year-old driver was arrested on a charge of dangerous driving causing grievous bodily harm.

;

;The city recorded 3,989 traffic accidents involving 6,600 vehicles in the first quarter of the year, according to the Transport Department. Private cars accounted for 37 per cent of the incidents, followed by taxis at 17 per cent, the most by any form of public transport.

;

;Put another way, at least 12 taxis, out of roughly 18,000 in total, get into an accident daily.

;

;Tougher health checks on Hong Kong drivers 'could spark minibus manpower woes'

;

;Quentin Cheng Hin-kei, a spokesman for commuter concern group the Public Transport Research Team, said he believed the recent cases were isolated incidents, but the city lacked a mechanism to spot drivers who were no longer fit to get behind the wheel.

;

;“It would be better if each cabby has to come under review regularly for their service quality and would be sent for training or get their licence suspended if they have committed misconduct,” he said. “But the industry has no motivation to do so because of the manpower crunch and the self-employed nature of taxi drivers.”

;

;Chow Kwok-keung, chairman of the Hong Kong Taxi and Public Light Bus Association, noted that almost half of taxi drivers were in their sixties, and said age could play a role in the number of accidents. The government has previously pledged to tighten health requirements for drivers over 65.

;

;“An eight-hour shift could be very challenging for senior drivers, but that's what it takes to earn a living for them,” he said, adding that some drivers worked 10 hours a day. “That's why we always ask the government to ease the licensing requirement and increase taxi fares, to attract more new blood.”

;

;Hong Kong cabbies want to slam brakes on annual health checks for drivers over 65

;

;Cabbies earn about HK$20,000 a month on average, and must sit a 45-minute written exam to obtain a licence, correctly answering at least 77 out of 90 questions to pass.

;

;Chow said the exam was quite difficult for some prospective drivers with less education than other workers, and were not used to sitting tests.

;

;“Many multiple-choice questions are quite impractical, like asking the location of certain buildings even though everyone uses GPS to navigate,” he said. “But one has to get 85 per cent of the answers correct to get a licence. That's definitely not easy.”

;

;Instead of going through the exam, younger people with a driving licence would instead join car-hailing services, which offered more flexibility in terms of hours and decent pay for a side job, Chow added.

;

;Dr Ryan Wong Cheuk-pong, chairman of the Hong Kong Taxi Council, said the round-the-clock presence of so many cabs on the road was likely a factor in their 17 per cent share of traffic accidents, but stressed passengers were not at greater risk simply because a driver was older.

;

;“From the statistics, we see most drivers that get into an accident are old, but we should not forget that most taxi drivers in Hong Kong are not young in the first place,” he said. “A simulation experiment we did with Polytechnic University found that senior drivers were indeed safer when driving, compared with the young ones because they knew their physical limits and would properly manage their risks.”

;

;Wong said the industry was working to make better use of technology to reduce the risk of accidents, including systems that warned drivers if they strayed out of their lane or were at risk of collisions, as well as devices that alerted drivers if they dozed off.

;

;Already, the government's Smart Traffic Fund has allowed for some of the devices to be installed in about 1,000 vehicles, but Wong called for more funding to help expand the coverage.

;

;He also agreed the current exam regime should be relaxed to attract younger drivers, a move that could allow them to screen out those with poor records.

;

;The Transport Department noted all taxi licence applicants had been required to take a course aimed at enhancing driving safety awareness since October 2020.

;

;To attract more new blood, the department has also relaxed the requirements for commercial vehicle driving licences, and adjusted the written exam questions to suit practical needs, it said.

; Thu, 22 Jun 2023 09:20:02 +0800 Hong Kong developers offer huge discounts, cut prices to 2018 levels for new project launches to boost saleshttps://www.scmp.com/business/article/3224926/hong-kong-developers-offer-huge-discounts-cut-prices-2018-levels-new-project-launches-boost-sales?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.22 08:30;
;;

;Buyers waiting to enter Hong Kong's property market could be spoiled for choice as some developers release homes at price levels last seen five years ago, looking to lock in sales before further anticipated increases in interest rates and supply.

;

;Developers are even offering sweeteners like mortgage discounts, dining and travel vouchers to exotic destinations like the Maldives to drum up sales.

;

;Many developers “are rushing to launch at prices close to or even lower than the market price”, said Louis Chan, the Asia-Pacific vice-chairman at Centaline Property Agency. “Ultimately, buyers will benefit.”

;

;While Chan expects the competitive pricing to attract buyers to the new homes market, “second-hand owners have no choice but to take a beating”.

;

;Henderson Land Development on Wednesday said it would offer the first batch of 148 flats in the 740-unit Henley Park in Kai Tak at an average of HK$21,088 (US$2,694) per square foot after discounts. The company, however, has yet to announce a launch date for the sales.

;

;The price is 15 per cent cheaper than leftover stock of new homes in the same district including Henderson's The Henley, according to Chan.

;

;Hong Kong's weekend home sale sags amid looming supply

;

;Last week after the Hong Kong Monetary Authority hit pause on rate hikes after several rounds of increases since March 2022, CEO Eddie Yue Wai-man warned that the cycle of rising interest rates was far from over.

;

;Bank of East Asia on Tuesday said it expected lenders to raise the prime rate by 25 basis points next month due to rising Hibor, which rose to 5.1 per cent on Tuesday, the highest level since 2007, and a tight aggregate balance.

;

;As the aggregate balance, or liquidity in the banking system falls, it results in higher funding costs for banks to borrow from other lenders, which they then pass on to their customers. The aggregate balance, meanwhile, has fallen to the lowest since 2008, according to Bloomberg.

;

;“The high interest rate is one of the points we have to address at this moment,” said Thomas Lam, general manager of sales at Henderson, adding that now is the time for buyers to enter the market.

;

;As the economy picks up in the second half, so will the demand, pushing prices higher, he added.

;

;Grand Ming Group on Wednesday priced 30 flats at the 76-unit The Grands in To Kwa Wan at an average discounted price of HK$18,526 per square foot, of which 24 flats are under HK$5 million.

;

;The starting price of HK$3.79 million for a 231 sq ft unit is the lowest for a new project in Kowloon this year and over 10 per cent cheaper than new launches nearby last year, according to Chan.

;

;The developer was concerned about the high interest rates and wanted to offer a competitive price to the buyers, said Shuooky Fung, general manager of sales and marketing, adding that the company “intended to increase the price of the next batch”.

;

;With Hong Kong's property market reeling, higher rates will dampen mood further

;

;Hip Shing Hong (Holdings) on Tuesday priced the initial batch of 50 units at the 156-unit Oria in Shau Kei Wan at an average of HK$23,042 per square foot after discounts. The price is the lowest for a new project on Hong Kong Island since 2018, according to Centaline's Chan.

;

;Prices start at HK$4.79 million after discounts for a 221 sq ft unit. Hip Shing Hong said it set the initial prices low to attract buyers and the price of the next batch would be adjusted accordingly.

;

;The Oria's average price, however, is higher than some lived-in projects completed in the district in recent years.

;

;Meanwhile, developers and agencies are going all out to offload leftover stock.

;

;Swire Properties on Wednesday said it would offer an extra 5 per cent discount for three flats at Eight Star Street in Wan Chai. The discount, however, is only valid from June 25 to July 31.

;

;Mortgage brokers are offering high rebates for Hibor-linked mortgages with a high loan-to-value ratio for the 105-unit Aruna by Chuang's China Investments in Ap Lei Chau.

;

;Centaline said it would give the first 10 buyers of the project in the medical profession and their families travel vouchers totalling HK$1.28 million.

;

;Midland Realty and Henderson are doling out dining vouchers worth a total of HK$120,000 for the first six buyers of four projects, including The Holborn in Sai Wan Ho.

;

;Hong Kong Property Services said it would give five buyers of The Knightsbridge in Kai Tak travel vouchers for the Maldives totalling some HK$680,000. The project is being developed by a consortium that includes China Overseas and Henderson.

;

;The developers' marketing offensive comes after new home sales in May sank 38 per cent to a three-month low of 942, according to Ricacorp Properties. The agency, however, expected transactions to rebound to above 1,000 this month.

;

;After home prices fell 15 per cent in 2022, developers continue to cut prices, Centaline's Chan said, adding it would take time for the economy to recover.

; Thu, 22 Jun 2023 08:50:02 +0800 US House approves Taiwan trade deal, demands future oversighthttps://www.scmp.com/news/china/article/3224948/us-house-passes-first-agreement-taiwan-trade-deal-demands-future-oversight?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.22 07:54;
;;

;The US House of Representatives on Wednesday voted to approve the first agreement signed under the US-Taiwan Initiative on 21st Century Trade and to require congressional consultation for future negotiations.

;

;The agreement, signed on June 1 under a framework for bilateral talks launched last year, covers streamlining customs procedures, combating corruption and helping small businesses navigate regulatory procedures in both markets. It broadly aims to strengthen the US-Taiwan trade and economic relationship, but does not include any market access provisions.

;

;Observers say the bill, which passed by voice vote and now moves to the Senate, is as much about asserting congressional authority over trade policy as it is about showing support for enhanced economic engagement with Taiwan.

;

;While the administration has the authority to negotiate such agreements if they don't require a change to US law, the political balance between executive decision-making and congressional oversight “is out of whack”, said Clete Willems, a partner at the Washington-based law firm Akin Gump Strauss Hauer & Feld.

;

;Willems said Wednesday's bill helped fill a void left by the expiration of trade promotion authority laws that guided the administration in negotiating deals. The Biden administration has not asked Congress for such authority, which is required to negotiate trade agreements with market access components.

;

;The legislation was announced earlier this month by bipartisan leaders in the Senate Finance Committee and the House Ways and Means Committee.

;

;Representative Jason Smith, the sponsor of the House bill and chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, said Wednesday: “The relationship between the United States and Taiwan is vital to US interest in the Indo-Pacific.”

;

;“This initial trade agreement negotiated by the Biden administration is a good step...it shows the world the Chinese Communist Party will not intimidate the United States from deepening our relationship with Taiwan,” he said.

;

;“Congress is sending a bipartisan message to President [Joe] Biden today that we will not sit idly by as the administration ignores our constitutional role in developing US trade policy,” added Smith, a Republican from Missouri.

;

;US-Taiwan trade initiative signals a shift in approach, analysts say

;

;The bill requires the Office of the US Trade Representative to show any future negotiating texts under the initiative to Congress before sharing with Taiwan or any parties outside the executive branch; provide daily briefings to Congress during negotiating rounds; and share any texts drafted by Taiwan within three days.

;

;It also requires that future agreements not take effect unless the US president makes the text publicly available 60 days before entering into the deal and a bill approving it is enacted into law.

;

;Rupert Hammond-Chambers, president of the US-Taiwan Business Council, said the agreement showed that there was “incremental ambition” for greater trade engagement with Taiwan.

;

;“It creates some momentum, it creates more ambition,” he said, noting the difference between the Biden administration and the “hostility” to trade agreements with Taiwan displayed under president Donald Trump.

;

;But as ambition continues to expand and more voices enter the fray, Hammond-Chambers said it would become harder for the two sides to conduct engagement through executive action.

;

;“In the absence of a broader consensus on trade and the hostility to free trade agreements in many quarters of the United States, navigating a robust aspirational trade policy toward Taiwan will become more complex,” he said.

;

;While the desire for a comprehensive free trade agreement may be mixed, Congress has increasingly signalled its desire for the US to step up economic engagement with Taiwan.

;

;Both chambers are currently considering a bill authorising the administration to negotiate a tax agreement with Taipei that would offer residents in the US and Taiwan relief from double taxation.

;Shanghai could be positioned to exert its influence as the “dragon's head” of China's economy, amid the city's new charm offensive to lure global investors, with both the economic hub and nation as a whole struggling to attract multinational companies.

;

;Seen as being at the forefront of China's bid to regain the confidence of foreign investors since its economic reopening, Shanghai is inviting overseas businesses to invest in high-quality projects through an enhanced “global investment partner” scheme, according to an official readout of a government meeting that took place on Monday.

;

;But its allure as a regional hub is decreasing among European companies, with a report by the European Union Chamber of Commerce in China on Wednesday showing that firms with Asia-Pacific headquarters in Shanghai dropped from 40 per cent last year to 33 per cent.

;

;“The idea of a global investment partner scheme was, in fact, brought up several years ago, but progress has been slow in the past couple of years because of the pandemic and heightened relations between China and the US,” said Shi Lei, a professor of economics from Fudan University.

;

;Shanghai's latest move is a further push for the introduction of high-end industries from overseas, as traditional domestic businesses continue to struggle amid a sluggish economic recovery.

;

;And while China has witnessed regionally unbalanced development in the past few years, Shanghai must exert its influence as the economy's “dragon's head”, he added.

;

;The city needs to expand foreign investment, especially by diversifying its partners, as China is faced with increasing containment efforts from the West, Shi said.

;

;“Now, via partnerships with the Middle East, Central Asia, and Central and South America, we may gradually shake off the dependence on Europe and North America,” he added.

;

;China kicked off a nationwide campaign to lure foreign businesses in March and has rolled out the red carpet for foreign executives, including Tesla CEO Elon Musk, who visited the carmaker's manufacturing plant in Shanghai at the start of June.

;

;In an apparent effort to reinforce its position as an international magnet for foreign investment, Shanghai is selecting a series of foreign companies that feature “strong capability, various channels, and standardised practices” to become its global partners, Mayor Gong Zheng said, according to the Shanghai Observer.

;

;It is hoped that this will lead the way for high-quality growth, a notion that China's top leadership has emphasised in recent years, Gong added, according to the city's official digital media platform.

;

;

;Officials at the meeting earlier this week also agreed on a three-year action plan through 2025 to build Shanghai into a global hub for exhibitions to introduce a series of industry leaders and cultivate industrial clusters, the platform said without adding further details for both plans.

;

;The moves follow an exodus of talent and businesses since Shanghai's two-month lockdown in 2022, while the interest in locating regional headquarters to the city among those who have stayed is falling.

;

;Less than 10 per cent of EU chamber's members who do not currently have their regional headquarters in Shanghai are considering relocating, the report said.

;

;Retaining existing multinationals and inviting new investors have been moved high up Beijing's agenda as it strives to attain a 5 per cent overall economic growth target for China this year.

;

;

;Actual use of foreign direct investment in China in the first five months of the year fell 5.6 per cent in US dollar terms.

;

;Shanghai will host more than 100 events by the end of the year to attract capital from overseas, the Shanghai Municipal Commission of Commerce said in April.

;

;The city is home to 902 multinational corporation regional headquarters and 536 foreign-funded research and development centres, according to the commission.

;

;A total of 11 multinational corporation regional headquarters and five foreign-funded research and development centres have been set up this year, the commission added.
